content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

As a human player, I would analyze the game strategically to maximize my earnings over the 75 rounds.

The payout matrix looks like this:

|   | R (You)    | B (Opponent) |
|---|---|---|
| R | (45,45)     | (0, 40)      |
| B | (40,0)      | (20,20)      |

Firstly, I notice that if both of us pick the same choice (R or B), our payoffs are higher than when we pick different choices. This suggests that it's advantageous to have a coordination strategy with my opponent.

Secondly, I observe that when picking R and my opponent picks B, I get 0$ while they earn 40$. However, since the game is repeated 75 times, this one-time loss of 40$ may not significantly affect my overall earnings if it balances out with the potential gains.

Thirdly, when picking B and my opponent picks R, I earn 40$, which seems like a better immediate payoff compared to choosing R and getting nothing. But again, considering the long-term impact of this choice, I might end up giving away too many points to my opponent and lose the game overall if they consistently choose R when I pick B.

Lastly, if we both pick B, we each earn 20$ per round, which seems like a safe bet. But since there's a higher payoff in picking R and hoping that my opponent also picks R (45$), I might be tempted to deviate from this strategy to try for the better outcome.

Taking all these factors into account, it's challenging to predict a definitive choice as a human player. However, I might lean towards choosing B initially, and if my opponent consistently chooses R when I pick B, I could switch to choosing R in subsequent rounds to exploit their apparent strategy. This approach is based on the idea of mixed strategies, which can be effective in repeated games like this one.

In conclusion, I would choose B as my initial strategy, with the intention of possibly switching to R if needed, appended as {B}.
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

Now that I have observed my opponent choosing R when I picked B in the previous round, I might adjust my strategy to exploit this information and aim for a higher payoff. In the next round, I would choose R, hoping that my opponent follows their initial choice pattern and chooses B.

This time around, if my opponent picks B as expected, I would earn 45$, while they get 0$. But if my opponent deviates from their observed strategy and chooses R again, I would get 0$ and they would earn 45$.
